user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_:
```c
bool
MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_ (struct MHD_Response *response,
                                  enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                                  char *header,
                                  size_t header_len,
                                  char *content,
                                  size_t content_len)
{
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *hdr;

  mhd_assert (0 != header_len);
  mhd_assert (0 != content_len);
  if (NULL == (hdr = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header))))
    return false;

  hdr->header = header;
  hdr->header_size = header_len;
  hdr->value = content;
  hdr->value_size = content_len;
  hdr->kind = kind;
  _MHD_insert_header_last (response, hdr);

  return true; /* Success exit point */
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_add_response_entry_no_alloc_:
#define mhd_assert(ignore) ((void)0)
...
#define MHD_calloc_(n, s) calloc((n),(s))
...
struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header
{
  /**
   * Headers are kept in a double-linked list.
   */
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *next;

  /**
   * Headers are kept in a double-linked list.
   */
  struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header *prev;

  /**
   * The name of the header (key), without the colon.
   */
  char *header;

  /**
   * The length of the @a header, not including the final zero termination.
   */
  size_t header_size;

  /**
   * The value of the header.
   */
  char *value;

  /**
   * The length of the @a value, not including the final zero termination.
   */
  size_t value_size;

  /**
   * Type of the value.
   */
  enum MHD_ValueKind kind;

}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No control statements in the function have invariant controlling expressions. The only conditional is: if (NULL == (hdr = MHD_calloc_ (1, sizeof (struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header)))) which depends on the runtime result of calloc and the assignment to hdr, so it is not invariant. There are no while, for, do-while or switch statements whose controlling expressions are compile-time constants. The mhd_assert invocations (mhd_assert (0 != header_len); mhd_assert (0 != content_len);) expand to ((void)0) per the provided macro definition, so they do not generate controlling expressions and therefore cannot violate Rule 14.3. The MHD_calloc_ macro expands to calloc((n),(s)), so the allocation check is runtime-dependent. Accordingly, there are no fragments in this function that require investigation for Rule 14.3.
